review_title: Why not made this character more athletic?

review_detailed_main: This topic is quite unusual because it is not talked about it very often. I come from eastern Europe and in our country it is normal for female person to be 6'1". Men are usually 6'4" so it is interesting to see something that is normal in one country in other is stigmatic. Nice romantic comedy and it shows how love has no rules.

Hate it. In this movie a tall girl gets a tall swedish guy crush and he never notices her and gets bullied. Her sister is a pageant queen and her mom is shorter and 'pretty' I like the tall girl character, going through bullying myself, but it portrays a very unrealistic harmful view to girls mainly (like me) showing that all your worth is for a guy. Having bad social anxiety, I related to the main girl character who feels single. (doesn't get invited to prom) and gets jealous understandably. I have been in this situation before.

Not really inspiring for females to be single or independent. Showing them 'all you need is a guy to be happy' and the kindest guy in the film didn't even get much attention. It's all about popularity and who's the best. I hated the popular girl who flirts with the new boy and found her soo annoying. She was really nasty as well. I don't think any guy in real life gets flirted with that much. It was sooo dumb. As if an average Swedish guy looks like that, he's a popular actor and gives false representations of men. A lot of good looking men in Sweden are 5'7, so it's putting them to shame.

The redeeming part of this movie is the often-witty and enjoyable script. That kept me entertained most of the way through. And overall I enjoyed the film.

However, a rather weak ending along with questionable plot elements pretty much knocked it off its perch. First: 6'1" is indeed a tall girl, and school kids can be very cruel and mean. But every high school basketball team in the nation would be after her... as would any music academy (she was presented as an excellent pianist). So that fact kept sticking out all through the film. (On the other hand, ask anyone who has ever been teased about being short or tall or not the body-idol norm... and they'll verify the experience.) High school can be horrid for those who aren't "part of the crowd".

Then there are the cliche characters... such as the older sister who pretty much had no purpose in the film at all. One might consider that between the two she was the actual "freak"... but it was a point poorly made and the part badly designed. The incompetent parent shtick, the all-knowing too-wise-for-their-age friends, the somewhat goofy principal... it's been done before. Lots.

But the biggest letdown (without spoilers) is the last 10 minutes of the movie, where it devolves into rather awful. The "microphone" scene was a complete wince moment that made me wonder what the writers were thinking (and what caused them to suddenly plunge to an after-school special mentality). The final few minutes while endearing were not enough to save the movie from what had gone just before. Ouch.

So all I can give this is a barely-above-mediocre 6 stars. I did find most of the movie entertaining, despite its flaws, but I do wish they'd have landed the ending better. It's like a plane that almost reaches its destination (with a lot of turbulence)... and then crash! Short of the runway.

The whole movie is all about a 6'2 girl who throughout the movie is bullied nonstop for being too tall. Throughout the whole movie, all of the events seem so artificial. This is most of these actors first or second movie and this does not help. Being 6'2 as a female in high school isn't a disease like this movie portrays. Second worst film i've ever seen right behind Amy Schumer's standup comedy.

Cast was pretty good, decent humour, satisfying conclusion, simple fun movie, no preachy political cringe which is a biiiiiiig plus for a 2019 movie.

Suited for younger audience.

I really don't get the hate for this movie as if most of the people who write the review is expecting and award worthy film. I don't care much about the Swedish accent since English isn't my native language anyway. I found the movie is fun but the script isn't really good at point and it really kind of cliche in a way. However I enjoy this movie as much and didn't expect that the main character didn't get the Prom Queen as I would think it is going to be which is great. I'm 5' 11" and 6" taller than average height in my country an 6'2" is really tall here (don't get it why some complaint she isn't tall enough).

review_title: I wish I could give this 0 stars.
review_detailed_main:
Tall Girl (2019) follows Jodi, a teenager who feels uncomfortable in her own skin due to her height, as she tries her best to gain confidence. This movie is terrible, with no redeeming qualities. I had no fun while watching and I couldn't wait for it to end.

The cinematography is bad, and you can tell no effort really went into it. The colour palettes are dull and the camerawork is lacklustre, the lighting is okay but very unimaginative. Additionally, the editing is too goofy, and not in a charming way. It just comes off as messy and irritating.

There isn't much to mention when it comes to the sound design, but the original score is terrible and incredibly grating. The soundtrack used is also very unfitting and makes the film feel even more messy.

The acting is bad from everyone, which isn't helped by the terribly written and dumb dialogue. The main character is extremely unlikable, and her best friend and eventual love interest, Jack, is even worse. Jodi and Jack have absolutely no chemistry, which makes the ending even more ridiculous and infuriating to watch. The writing feels super out of touch when it comes to teenagers and I can't think of anything nice to say about it!

Lastly, Tall Girl (2019) is a fast paced mess of a film, and not enjoyable in the slightest. The plot is so dull with no driving force, resulting in a movie that is almost painful to watch. The ending left me angry and I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone.

review_title: Netflix Movie: Tall Girl (2019)- Review by Divyam Saran
review_detailed_main: I recently saw the movie, Tall Girl (2019), which is a Netflix rom-com movie. I came to know about this film because it is produced by one of my favourite producers McG who has earlier made films like Charlie's Angels, Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle and Terminator Salvation. The movie is a good treat for the teens and college-going class. The film begins with Jodi Kreyman (Ava Michelle), who due to her abnormal height is not able to involve in any sort of relationship with her college mates. Though her role is quite serious, there are moments with a lighter note too. Paris Berelic plays the role of Liz who is Jodi's best friend and serves as a source of constant motivation for her. Sabrina Carpenter plays the role of Jodi's sister and an aspiring model. Griffin Gluck plays the role of Dunkleman who is Jodi's childhood friend and is in love with her. The events of the film take a drastic turn when the second main protagonist, Stig Mohlin (Luke Eisner), a foreign exchange student enter Jodi's college. I would like to mention that the cast does not disappoint us but I still consider it to be a very ordinary project. The storyline too is very ordinary while the screenplay and direction are fine. The matter of the fact is that the movie holds you till the end and does not bore you. If I summarize in two lines, I would say, Tall Girl, is not a movie with depth. It has nothing new or fresh to bring to the genre. I would give this film an average rating of 6 stars and would advise that if you have free time this weekend then give this movie a one-time watch.

This is a movie best appreciated by adolescents. It's about the pains of feeling awkward as you grow up, and you don't have to be a tall girl to appreciate that message. It's a sweet story. Not a groundbreaking teen movie by any means, but a nice one.

review_title: Tall Girl: A Film Not To Watch
review_detailed_main:
"Tall Girl" falls short in addressing important themes like self-acceptance and body image. The film's execution lacks depth and authenticity, opting for simplistic messages that don't explore the complexities of these issues. Instead of offering meaningful insights, it relies on tired clichés, failing to deliver empowering moments.

Visually, the film is unremarkable, with uninspiring cinematography that fails to capture the audience's attention. The low-budget production values further diminish the viewing experience.

In summary, "Tall Girl" is a forgettable teen rom-com that brings nothing new to the genre. Its predictable plot, shallow characters, and superficial treatment of important themes make it hard to connect with or find any redeeming qualities. It leaves no lasting impression and lacks a compelling and meaningful story.
One of the most trash movies i've ever seen, and i watch a lot of trash movies. The script was written by an isolated 5 year old that probably never saw the world, and all the actors r trash. peace.

I really enjoyed it and was sad to see so many negative reviews. No, it's not a deep intellectual commentary on modern day teenagers. I would compare it to YA romance. If that's not your thing, you'll probably find this movie too light and fluffy, but I personally like the "love the skin you're in" teen romance. So, for me, this film checked off all the right boxes and left me with all the feels.

Ps. I LOVED the ending. *warm, fuzzy feels*
She should come and live in the netherlands. Every dutch girl is around her size 😂

If you completely ignore that this is a movie, and you take a shot everytime they make a joke about Tall Gorls height. Then it's laughable at best and a palm to the face at worst. So if taken seriously as a teen drama, its -1/10. But as a (bad) comedy, it's at least 4/10.

review_title: My 14-year-old daughter made me watch this as a form of torture
Highschool rom com speaking American culture
review_detailed_main:
Comedy Romance

Simply good and liked it when watching.

The concept simply was clear and definetely it would be the culture in America. In India, we can find hell a lot of these kind of classrooms with similar plots..

Thats is different and this Tall Girl speaks about her personal feeling at the high school and people around her. The script had fun all over the play and sentiments as well.

All the characters were provided with good weightage and ending.
Although it had a clear positive message this movie was predictable. The overall message was what made this movie. I enjoyed most of it.

Hey everyone, remember Precious? The harrowing tale of an obese, illiterate black girl growing up on the mean streets of 1980's Harlem? Raped by her father, beaten by her mother, and impregnated twice by the age of sixteen, one child being born with Down Syndrome? Oh yeah, AND her father gave her HIV to go with it?

Well in Tall Girl we have - brace yourself - a girl who's tall. I know, I had trouble processing it too. Game-changing and not for the faint of heart, this brave new movie punches the most terrifying of subject matters: a girl who's taller than her peers. So if you found Precious an uneasy watch, buckle up; Tall Girl surpasses that territory and goes beyond. I mean, she's...TALL, guys! How could anyone face such a reprehensible burden? Sure, it works for supermodels, female athletes and Olympic medallists, but putting them aside, no-one could ever conceive what a traumatic life tall people lead. Kudos to this remarkable film for recognising that long-ignored problem through an uncomfortably candid lens.

Jodi's self-inflicted insecurity is something all too many giants suffer from, it's high time they were acknowledged. Just listen to the breath-taking way she reveals at the start of this movie, 'You think your life is hard? I'm a high school junior wearing size-13 trainers. MEN's size-13 trainers. Beat that.' Wow. Preach it, sister. Certainly puts things in perspective, doesn't it? I know the next time I watch Precious, I'll be looking at the titular outcast and thinking, "Get a grip, girl. So you've been put through years of violent abuse by your own parents, we've all been there. Now the lead star of Tall Girl, on the other hand - talk about untapped. Her classmates keep asking her the lazy, uninspired question, 'How's the weather up there?' Now THAT'S drama! Real problems that people can relate to! Finally, someone out there gets it!"

God, I hate my generation.

review_title: Maybe I'm not the target audience?
review_detailed_main:
I was excited for this movie when it came out because I liked Ava on Dance Moms. I thought it would be great. But I hated this movie. I tried so hard to like it but any time I wasn't horrifically bored, I was cringing at the awkward writing. I don't think the script went through more than one draft. I had to break my watch time out over 2 days. I was really determined to give this movie a chance to redeem itself, which is why I continued it the next day. It just got worse though. I hated every second of it. I hated every character. After a certain point I gave up on redemption and watched to see how bad the ending would be. It was bad. I hated the ending.

We needed Jodi to go serve in a soup kitchen or volunteer at an animal shelter and realize why she is not the center of the universe. That's not what we got. Everyone involved with this production deserved better.

I have always been the tall girl at school, even though when I think of it I'm not that tall but the majority of the girls in the school are below average in height. They have always gave me that sense that I'm too tall but I have now realized that they were insecure about their own height. Most of the things in this movie are true especially "How's the weather up there". It took me a couple of years to be confident about my height but now I am. I related so badly with this film. I love it! I hope it encourages other girls to be confident in their own body too.
It's cancer it's cringe and i hate the main character ........

review_title: Worth a watch but nothing groundbreaking
Love a film that looks to shame and categories more people.
review_detailed_main: I was and never have been shamed or looked down on for my height, only complimented on it. If I were a teen watching this it would most likely trigger an insecurity that is highly unnecessary. If only producers thought twice about the messages they're sending out to a younger audience - oh and not to mention, of course it is a female shamed for her natural beauty.

Why won't they have an actual Swede as an actor rather than American who barely knows anything about Sweden.

Also just the whole movie is just awkward and so on, definitely wouldn't recommend watching >=[

I love the multiple scenes where the lead walks by other girls who are as tall or barely shorter than her. Also it's 6'2"... also why does every main character get a prom speech? Nobody would have cared.

review_title: I am very confused with the very negative reviews of this movie!
review_detailed_main: I am 6 foot tall woman. I grew to this height in 1 year at the age of 13. At 12 years old was not alone in my height but by 13 years old I was very much alone. There were no boys or girls in my high school who were as tall as me. I was not treated very well. If they weren't bulling me then they just avoided me as they saw potential issues with the other kids if they were seen with me. I was not a bad looking girl but I stooped trying to be smaller which didn't help my image. I wanted so much to be shorter. So to the women who have reviewed this movie so disparagingly and to the other who rated so low for other reasons I really don't understand you take. The movie was well acted, the script was good and the message was lovely. I have a 11 year old great niece who loved the movie and the message. I have seen much worse movies that have better reviews than this one so I really wonder at the way this movie has been disparaged. I for one identified with it. I wish I had gone to the prom and spoke up like she did. I wish I had had the guts to join the drama club at high school. I wanted to so much but just couldn't face it. I wondered what I would have been cast as? A boy? This would have been too hard for a 13 year old girl who just wanted to have boys interested in her. Yes I wasn't full of courage but I wasn't and that is sometimes how it is.
If you wanna kill yourself, but can't get yourself to do it... just watch this! It will push you over the edge.

Tall Girl fails if for no other reason then the fact that being tall is not something anymore gets bullied for or is something to be self conscious about. Everyone likes tall kids in high school because they are good at sports. Whose dumb idea was this to make this movie?

This movie is like every other bad teen movie Netflix keeps giving the green light to. The characters themselves were one dimensional and not likable except maybe the short boy that liked the main character. It has bad writing and is a waste to watch.

Being the same height as the girl in this movie, I kept thinking: Get over yourself!!! Or move to The Netherlands. I don't know what the average height in the US is, but this movie seems to be filmed in Lilliput and Jodi is Gulliver. The story of this movie isn't better or worse than so many other b-movies, but it has no credibility whatsoever if you make a girl that's only 6'1"(and a half) look like she's a giant. And of all the girls and women I know who are the same height or even taller, NO ONE wears shoes in size 13.

A really beautiful story, but some of the "funny" scenes are actually not so funny, some predictable moments, and the plot is just too fast-moving. My favorite characters are Dunkleman and Fareeda, I think they carry the whole movie on their backs, lol. Stig the exchange student is gorgeous but kinda dumb. As for Jodi the female lead, she's kinda relateable. Also, the ending is beautiful and gives a good message.

Yeah I get it, being different can really suck. But here's the thing. The "tall girl" in this movie is not only just marginally taller than average. She's also pretty, intelligent and comes from a middle class family. Seriously what's the problem?

I'll tell you what the problem is, her victim complex is the problem. In any other universe a girl like this could be the star of her girl's basketball or volleyball team. She'd have guys who are close to her height dogging her constantly. Hell she'd have average guys who couldn't get a date hitting on her because nobody else would. But no because she can't get a date in this bizarro universe this is the problem.

And of course it ends with a message about body positivity and how everybody should love the body they're in. Nice message but it's totally wasted on this drivel.

Okay so i'm swedish, we aren't "giants" here, but the moment that made me turn this off was when the "swedish" exchange student had a GERMAN ACCENT. NETFLIX DID YOU VISIT THE WRONG COUNTRY FOR RESEARCH OR DID YOU JUST GOOGLE THE BLUE AND YELLOW FLAG AND THOUGHT "HEY THIS'LL DO!" ren skit. translate that

'im a high school junior wearing size 13 nikes. MENS size 13 nikes. beat that'. idk about yall but i know middle school girls who are 6 ft 1 and wear big shoes. im a hs jr, i know senior girls who are 4 ft 11, and I know ones who are way over 6 ft 1 i thought this movie was a joke at first. a white blonde girl isnt gonna get bullied just for her height. try being a bisexual, transgender asian.

Message of the movie was that tall girls aren't not freaks. Well, nobody was actually saying that, and the tall girls were not thinking that. But they are now. They also go out of their way to imply that short guys are unwanted. Not cool.

This is the most ridiculous take on the "outcast high schooler" that has ever been made. This movie should not have been made. The dialogue is PAINFUL and there is zero chemistry between any of the characters. Basically, awkward as hell. Enjoy!

Written by a 65 (is the new 55) year old earthling. Cute little Netflixer, predicable when based on teasing kids/teens being insensitive to their peers. If there's something different about you, kids will gladly tease you about it. Which gave me a reason to drop a tear, because in real life, some kids can't cope.

First of all, it's not a comedy film. It didn't even try to make a joke. Secondly, the main heroine feels depressed because no one loves her, so she friendzoned the guy who actually loves her... Then Tall Girl showed, that all you need for love is make-up and the most beautiful boy in school is more important than friends. I'm not a feminist, but even for me this film seems so immoral.

I made this account just to write a bad review on this low, shallow, unrealistic movie. It filled me up with such disdain. The main character was uncharacteristically mean to her friends & overall just shallow. You know what, not even uncharacteristically; from the beginning to end she was just a poorly written character who I was not rooting for. God bless the actors with their poorly written scripts; the actors were one of the only shining parts of this movie. I would go on, but, there's no need to. The 1/10 stars should speak for itself. Me & my gf watched this movie ironically & even then it committed the worst movie sin of all: It was boring. It's not even good to watch ironically. Erroneous. That's the best word for it.

This movie so bad and so unrealistic that it hurts, please tell me who gets bullied for being tall, like "HAHA, You can reach the top shelf and I can't!!!!!!". Honestly, if Netflix is going to make a movie for teens make it good.

I honestly could not finish this movie. Got to the one hour and 40 minute mark and decided I had had enough. From the first two minutes you can tell the dialogue is going to be garbage. It felt so inorganic and stale. It was cringe inducing. The "mean" jokes towards Jody were painfully embarrassing. "More like taller Swift," lol. Dear God, it didn't even attempt to be creative. What's even worse is the way people reacted to the joke. Like, "Oh, good one Kimmy." Is this real? Is this a real film? I felt like I was watching a parody. Someone actually wrote this, and an entire cast and crew filmed it. THAT IS INSANE!

The editing was also unbearable. There were so many unnecessary, distracting cuts and glaring continuity errors. Some cuts literally felt like a film student's second attempt at Premiere.

But by far the movie's worst mistake, its worst sin is, it treats being tall-a universally desired physical trait-like some sort of mayor deformity. In the beginning I though the film was being a little sarcastic and self-aware of its premise, but no. It takes the issue pretty seriously. And the problem doesn't lie in the main character being insecure about her above average height. You can have a pretty good movie about an attractive, tall character who is just insecure and unsure of herself. The problem lies in the way everyone reacts to her height. It's just not realistic in the slightest. You have an attractive main character with the physical attributes of a model, and everyone around her acts like she's Godzilla. I'm sorry, I just didn't buy it.

One thing the movie did right was her parents. It makes perfect sense that Jody would be so insecure with such a knucklehead of a father. If the movie had gone that route and focused more on the theme of her dad's insecurities affecting her self esteem, I think we would have a much better movie. Problem is, the movie doesn't understand subtlety, so it's not just her parents and one or two jerks here and there that have a problem with her tallness; it's EVERYONE. And I know the actress that played Jody had a rough time because of her height, but come on. An entire high school acting like they've never seen someone above five feet-in the United States of America, no less-is a bit of a stretch.

In conclusion, I did not enjoy this movie. It was boring, the characters were flat, I didn't feel the slightest bit of sympathy for the main character, the guy she ends up with is a manipulative creep, and it's just a bad movie all around. It's not even the premise. It's the way it's executed.

review_title: Well, I loved it. So there.

review_detailed_main: As a Swede, I'm once again blown away by how difficult it seems for you people to get hold of a real swedish person. There are more then ten million of us. But hey, that makes sense because a Swede would've never said yes to that. We're not that basic. Nor are we giants. We're hot though, I'll give you that. Seriously, if this (and other high school movies) is any indication of how American teenagers interact, you should take a long good look at how you raise your children over there. Hej då!

review_title: It sucks to be tall, and rich?
review_detailed_main:
I'm not in the mood to write in full sentences for this review, so I'll stick with key words and phrases, which is all this film deserves (or contains).

Script: hackneyed, not a good retelling of a classic storyline for a new generation (Pretty in Pink), majority of scenarios and character choices do not make sense

Direction/Editing: typical Instagram style - bright colors, clean everything, failed attempts at height based slapstick

Acting: people dying on swords left and right to make a terrible script work - actors gotta eat somehow - but overall, it's hard to make crap look good

Overall: not worth your time

review_title: Tall Girl's familiar teen love story fails to reach new heights.
review_detailed_main: From a one-note mean girl stereotype to a complete disinterest in how social media shapes the lives of teens, Sam Wolfson's lackluster script fails to bring anything new or timely to the teen rom-com table.

Everyone, only exceptions being her two best friends, taunt Jodi for her height all day every day. She's not the new girl or someone they haven't seen before so it's ridiculous she's treated like a freak of nature on a constant basis DAILY, even by her own family! I was expecting her to be closer to 7 feet tall under the circumstances but she's 6'1? Seriously?

Her dad considered having her hormones suppressed while she was very young even though one of the side effects is infertility. That's too far which sets the pace of how ridiculous she's treated because of her height when it's not even that tall.

They seemed to go out of their way to cast short people because she's way taller than everyone, guys included, at only 6'1. They must not have any basketball teams at her school or her city/town for that matter.

It would have been more relatable or realistic if she was just the tallest girl, which is what I was expecting. Her shoe size and all that isn't that hard to accommodate these days because of internet shopping too. They made it seem impossible but it would have been more believable if her frustration was because she can only order from online and not off the rack but no. They implied she can't get anything anywhere since she wears a 13 in men's. My oldest wears a 15 and I could get him shoes even at Walmart so I'm confused lol

Her friend loves her the way that she is and she overlooks that because he's shorter than her (and most people). How ironic is it that she judges him for his height when she hates that she is?

They miss the mark so many times and ways. It's frustrating because it had potential. Her families obsession with beauty and what THEY deem normal was gross and unnecessary. I cringed at most of what they said and did, ugh.

You could say that, with a height of 1.81m, i would be the targeted audience for this movie. But, here comes the big BUT.

In general i like the message this movie is trying to communicate. But the way it does this or TRIES to do this is horrible.

The whole story is failing to be believeable at all. Besides Jodie, there is not really a character that you like. Maybe her best friend, but that's really it. The story tries really hard to be thoughtfull and give everyone a good feeling, but it just didn't got to me. Felt like the movie was pretending to be something really deep when it wasn't even touching the surface of being a tall girl.

review_title: As a tall girl i related to it
review_detailed_main: Its a nice movie. I liked it. It was relatable because when I used to be in school I used to have aaall the same confidence problems. But in reality movie wasn't that amazing. GOOD BUT NOT AMAZING. And what the hell with Jodi's makeup and outfits? Just nono. And Griffin is sooo cute 😍

review_title: Felt bad about giving it 1 star
review_detailed_main: Truly cringe worthy. Was hoping for this years Sierra Burgess is a Loser but was disappointed. Movie wanders aimlessly for an hour and a half before reaching the predictable conclusion offering nothing new to the conversations around body positivity, bullying or self acceptance. Save yourself. Re-watch Sierra.
I am just curious why someone to read this scenario and to actually decide to produce the movie! Its so bad!!
I heard so many bad things about this movie and decided to watch it. In my opinion, twilight is better.

This movie is about Jodie. She is a member of the most oppressed demographics today. Tall and attractive women. If anything, this movie is an insult to people with real issues. It is dumb and pointless. That's all there is to say about it.

This movie had its few little faults, but it is SO powerful and inspirational especially when you have lived that life and have felt those struggles.

In a world where most people strive to be body positive I feel tall woman are always overlooked, so it was really wonderful to see it brought to life in such a feel good and real fashion. It was awkward and hard to watch at times, but that's REAL! That's LIFE!

10/10 will watch again!

review_title: When are we gonna stop making spoiled children shows
review_detailed_main: Just stop. people have bigger problems. It's just annoying to watch these kinds of shows, imagine these kids actually encountering real life problems and not some spoiled teen drama stuff. This is why when spoiled privileged people don't have any real problems they'll look for any small thing, likely the case with feminists and cancerous "girl empowering" stuff.

Seriously by putting high being a problem. What is this world. Seriously. STATE REAL PROBLEMS INSTEAD. Like climate change, food hunger or suicide static's. Id being tall actually a problem? NOO. Maybe guys don't find you attractive and so on. But it makes the veiw of a girl messed up. Why should a girls feel bad for being tall. LILE JOIN THE BASKET TEAM. Use ur unique body for something positive STAWP being so ungrateful for the world. And spend energy on real things.

This movie did not seem to achieve what it had aimed for. They made 6'1 seem weirdly tall, when in reality there are many people at that height. And are you telling me there was only one guy taller than her in the whole school? Where's the basketball team we see in every other high school movie?! It was obvious they wanted this exact person to play the role, because of her fame beforehand on "Dance Moms", knowing they would attract the fan base. Also, the other characters weren't written well, with the stereotypical best friend of a quiet girl and a boy who's madly in love with someone who doesn't even notice. The movie tried to make being taller a good thing, but it backfired terribly, achieving the opposite.
Idk how to explain it but it wasn't that good and was quite bad. I wouldn't recommend this

review_title: Had a chance to stand out, but didnt.

review_detailed_main:
There is a similar movie in Japan about a tall girl called Lovely Complex and being tall in Asia for a girl is head-turning, so the story is pretty relistic.

I don't think this is realistic in western countries, though.

review_title: The message was basically 'don't alienate me because I'm tall', yet the fact that this is a movie does just that.
review_detailed_main:
You don't have to make a whole movie about how a girl is insecure about her height. It's like making a movie about a girl who's insecure about her big nose. Yes, maybe it's noticeable, but that's the worst it is, people don't care about you enough to give you a hard time about something you can't control.

Ugh, and her parents! You'd think they'd have got used to the idea that their daughter is tall by now but they still seem to bring it up a LOT. Further alienation, also unrealistic.

I can understand how a tall girl might feel a bit insecure about her height, but please, people mostly don't care enough to bully you about it. The worst you'd get is someone looking in your general direction, thinking 'oh wow! She's quite tall!', and then going about their day. Honestly, her being insecure about her height is more due to her wildly insecure personality rather than her actual height.

review_title: She's not that tall! Swedish guys aren't that good looking either! Ridiculous and annoying movie
review_detailed_main: First of all, main character Jodi isn't extremely tall (187 cm) - I know a girl my age (16) who is 198 cm. And as this movie is taking place in the US; where the heck are all tall people? I mean there's a great diversity in the States. Second, tall people aren't getting bullied as much as short people, on the contrary! My friends who are under 160 cm get bullied and they are discriminated like not being able to work as a flight attendant etc; and as we all know short people are having more difficulties in general getting a good job etc etc - all top ranked CEO's are tall. Really weird that Jodi's sister is a beauty pageant being 152 cm - that's very very short and absolutely too short for a beauty contestant. So even though tall girls can get bullied when young it's nothing comparing to how short women get treated in their lives. Second, this "swedish" guy Stig (Stig and Ingvar aren't at all common today except for old men around 70) doesn't even speak swedish and his accent doesn't sound at all swedish, more like a weird german maybe. But I have to say that I almost laughed when Stig talked about not being tall or even good looking comparing to other swedish guys in general - if you come to Sweden with this idea you'll be very very disappointed!
Interesting concept but this film falls flat due to its cringey dialogue, terrible acting and the terrible third act.

review_title: John Hughes Set The Bar High
review_detailed_main:
The high concept. (pun intended) The story is engaging. The humor held my attention.

The reality is the audiences watching this film, Millennials, are so saturated with self evaluation that they are numb to Free Will. Laugh. Cry. Fart. Repeat.

The parents in John Hughes films were always real and invested in their kids, and we saw them parenting. We, as the audience, listened to them.

In Tall Girl, the parents are almost invisible and that's what hurts it.

On the upside: it's not the self - righteous Booksmart.

I believed the story I saw and I laughed.

But the fact remains John Hughes was to the teen genre what John McTiernan was the Action film.

Sorry i cant even get thru till the end. Story feels straight up written from the 80s complete with all cringeyness except shes tall. Which probably doesnt affect anything if they exclude that factor even. A timid girl with outspoken best friend + hot mean girl + handsome boy bla bla boring.

First of all the character "Stig" was super stereotypical and totally unrealistic. Like when she is complaining about her shoe size. Some people have real problems and she is just like "mEns SIzE 13 NikeS oH No" this stole movie is really unrealistic and overall really dumb. I do not recommend at all

review_title: I Can't Believe This Came Out in 2019

review_detailed_main: I just take like 2 hours watching a movie which has no point at all . The story is awful and somehow not realistic and the cast isn't that good. I've never regretted watching a movie, but I did regret watching this.

I refuse to believe that being 1.80/6'2 would make you stand out like that. It's not really the tall.

Also, I've never seen it heard of someone being as nasty as the "antagonist" of the story. Just because it's a movie cliche that people will do anything horrible to mess with you, doesn't mean it's realistic.

The worst thing for me was the payoff of the movie, that outfit was so ridiculously ugly, my god.

review_title: It's a good movie but it has some awkward moments
Most of the movie was a 6-7 but the end

review_detailed_main: 5/10 - problematic and ridiculous in its plot (I mean to think that literally no one at the school is above 6' 1" and that this girl is the "most oppressed" in the school), but it has a killer soundtrack and some kind of perfect moments (aka Fareeda's entrance set to "Karaoke")

I have a love hate relationship with coming of age movies and usually I either hate them or love them and this one was no different it didn't have any moments where I really cared about the characters problems and it wasn't funny at and unrealistic at it's finest like it took place in New Orleans and you're telling me in just supposed to believe that there were barely any black people also how was she the tallest in that school have you been to New Orleans there are some y'all men

As a tall girl who went through an amount of bullying during school I though this movie will be something I could relate to, unfortunately it turned out to be just piece of garbage. Terrible acting, writing, directing. The whole story is absolute rubbish and shallow. Don't waste your time.

review_title: Tall Girl Reaches New Heights in my Disappointment
I'm not a 6 foot tall woman
review_detailed_main: I'm a 5'11" dude, but that's not why I'm reviewing this. I didn't enjoy it because it empowered me, I enjoyed it cause it was hilarious and didn't make me depressed about the world. Usually I'm picky with my movies and stingy with ratings, but there are only so many "masterpiece" films I can watch that all tell me the world is a dark and disturbing place. I'm gonna make it a point to start watching feel good movies that are bad in the satisfying ways. This was like Max Keeble's Big Move, but for Gen Z. Cheers to the "bad" movies out there!

review_title: Remake of Pretty in Pink, maybe?
review_detailed_main: Seems so much like the old school movie, so many of the characters seem to follow the same style of character with modern day twists.

The worst thing that could happen to a woman is... big feet and being tall? Yikes.... Moral of the story: Girls and women can accept their hideously tall bodies and hideously enormous feet as long as they are validated by a male--the hot "Swedish" exchange student. Regressive. I didn't even make it through the first episode.

I'm 6'1 and my shoe size is a ladies 10. When I first saw his trailer, I thought it would be funny. I hoped it would've reflected my childhood. But they made so unrealistic. Yes I was teased, but not like that. They could've done so much better.

review_title: cute, but not the right content for 2019
So many unfair and silly criticisms of this film. It's a winner!
review_detailed_main:
I scanned all the reviews and it seemed like the negative ones were driven by:

C-Sections were criticized (WHAT?) The Swedish character didn't sound perfectly Swedish (Who cares?) Or they were demanding someone to do John Hughes only better (?) It's Netflix so it sucks

Do so many people have a single axe to grind that they ignore a good effort and one of the few movies on Netflix where people DON'T get killed???

I'm just glad I watched it before looking at these baseless reviews. And by the way---why are so many reviews REPEATED over and over---WEIRD.

I loved it. Anyone that wasn't in the most popular crowd in High School can probably relate. The Tall Girl is representative of all the non athletic, tubby, too short, freckled, somewhat pimply or just not socially hip kids. Which is to say the MAJORITY.

The movie is pretty straight forward. Not difficult to follow. I CAN'T say the same for the reviews!

Compliments to the cast. I think they did a great job with a script that isn't John Hughes at his best but is moving and heartfelt.

Are producers supposed to stop making teen films because they may not be as good as 'Breakfast Club'???

If you're softhearted, watch it. If you have kids that are in junior high, watch it with them. It will be meaningful for you both.
This movie is so unrealistic and cheesy. This would never happen and she's not even tall. They obviously casted short men and used absurd camera angles to make her look tall. Genuinely hard to watch.

I watched this with my 15 year old niece and even she though it was beyond tacky and distasteful. The whole concept of the movie is centered around basically bullying in schools but this is so overly dramatic to the point its distasteful. The script is awful.

review_title: The sum-up of all bad shows made by Netflix
review_detailed_main: I don't understand how these bad shows/movies even get the go-ahead to be produced. First of all 6' 1'' is not that tall, yet, everyone else seemed tiny compared to her; where was it filmed, midget ville? Second, where was the "amazing and smart girl" her friends talked about? All I saw was a moaning, slightly tall girl who moped around school unhappily for no particular reason. And the not-so-hot and definitely not-so-Swedish guy with the personality of a pencil who realises that his mean girlfriend is mean after all... A riveting plot by all accounts. This movie is a whole new level of bad, even for Netflix

I'm cancelling my Netflix subscription, I mean how can they justify the increase by making movies like this.

It's getting even more worst for Netflix I'm failing to understand the content they are making now days. It's like taking your girlfriend to the movie in a lambo and dropping her back off in a Ford.

The movie it self was ok but not ok enough that I will say I want to watch it again. It was like watching a dog barking meow. Anyways that sums it up for me.

review_title: i am offended as a woman.
review_detailed_main: Honestly, i watch trashy teen films weekly, and this is one of the worst ones i have seen. and it was made in 2019? i mean? first, this movie features girls hating on girls, and i mean aren't we tired of this? second, stalker-y behavior is shown as the nice guy-friend-best suitor and this is seriously disturbing and concerning, teaching kids watching this that this is acceptable behavior.

I am just trying to understand why these reviews on films are not according to the genre and the age of the target audience...

This movie is great! I has everything a teenage or person feeling allienated should feel. It offers a solution for those feeling alone and out of place.

The characters are strong and very charismatic, the plot is surprising and the little details make the whole difference!

Do watch this movie if you want to heal from feeling different!

review_title: I watched it so you wouldn't have to.
review_detailed_main:
This is the worst Netflix has to offer, worse than Kissing Booth even. The characters have no depth, the tall girl lacks personality, she's boring and whiny. The others keep calling her fun but we see none of that in the actual movie? The "Swedish" guy has a laughable accent, the "mean girl" is just a hollow shell that says kind of mean things sometimes. The dialogue is awkward and cringy. Don't get me started with that "quirky" crate thing that was supposed to turn into this "cute" stroke of genius moment at the very end. So predictable and just awful.

Not only are the characters and acting terrible, the whole concept of this movie is idiotic, people don't get bullied for their height, that doesn't happen. I'm a very tall girl, always the tallest in class, taller than my older siblings, and I love it. Being tall is great, that shouldn't be a "movie screen realisation".

review_title: A not-very-good film with potentially dangerous messages for young women
review_detailed_main: The message of this film is that it doesn't matter what you look like - except it actually does, and you must have a makeover before anyone will notice/love you. I could have maybe forgiven that if it had actually been any good - but it's not very funny and the story is so unrealistic (similarly to the Swedish guy's accent). The one good thing about it is the older sister who gets the only good lines - but the fact that she's a beauty queen doesn't exactly break the feminist mould. There are much better teen flicks to watch on Netflix (The Kissing Booth, All The Boys I've Loved Before) so don't bother with this one.

Okay okay.

There's was no real struggle. She was 6 ft not 8.

review_title: A good try, but a terrible movie
review_detailed_main: This was painful to watch. I mean, this movie preaches MALE VALIDATION which should not be preached! The fact that she needed the boys and everyone else to realise her is just a little sociopathical and she is such a horrible friend! And the make out scene is REALLY culty. Has anyone realised that she actually isn't that tall? They hired shorter actors, for example, Sabrina carpenter that plays Harper is actually 1.5m tall. Also they use low camera angles to make her look taller and higher camera angles to make everyone else look smaller. I admire that the actor Ava overcame her height issues and that is great but I think that making a cringey movie about it is a bit too much. The most generic American movie I have ever seen.

review_title: Jodi was the actual mean girl in this whole film
review_detailed_main:
Usually I'm a huge fan of these teen romance films that Netflix pushes out, but this one was like a roller coaster of emotions and I'm still not even sure I liked it.

Jodi Kreyman (Ava Michelle) is the joke of the school because of her "unusual" large height. Feeling left out and just wanting to find someone she can connect with, in comes exchange student Stig Mohlin (Luke Eisner) who shares a similar height. Jodi who doesn't seem to have any other goals in the film, drops everything including her friends to try win over the handsome exchange student.

I honestly don't know what the message was in this film... Like I get the simple message at the end, but it was done in such a poor form. Jodi ditched her only friends, and went out of her way to look good for a guy to notice her. Are we trying to teach kids that if school students are making fun of how you look, you should up your game with new clothes and makeup so people look at you in a more respectful way? The way Jodi treated her two friends was so bad. They always had her back and Jodi was so quick to turn away from them when she didn't like what was she hearing.

The ending is cute, but yeah the messages are so bipolar and all over the place.

Tall girl is a story about a high school girl who struggles with her height and gets picked on everyday by students in school. I have heard that many people find this movie quite unrelatable but I can definitely see how a teenage girl would feel insecure about fitting in, especially in an environment like hers. It's a fast pacing movie. However, the script is as if it were written by a twelve-year old. The main characther constantly repeats how much of a freak she is in conversations that have nothing to do with this topic. Overall, I don't see a person above the age of 14 enjoying this. I would've given the movie a lower rating if it weren't for the ending, which I honestly thought was quite cute.

Ava Cota does a nice job in her first lead role, making Jodi as written come to life. Her emotions rang true and her personality underwent no drastic changes despite a spectacularly unrealistic ending.

Also, I give the film makers credit for doing a high school movie sans jocks and cheerleaders. However, therein also lies a chunk of the false premise the script is built on: that tall girls in 2019 are outcasts.

Since the advent of Title IX in the 1970s, as opportunities for girls to play sports increased and female students were drawn to taking part, height became a desired trait to many at any high school. Basketball -- Jodi does reference people calling her "Lebron" but doesn't seem to be on the Ruby Bridges High team -- volleyball, swimming, track and field all prize height at certain positions or events. As girls and boys grow up together watching each other in sports, there is nothing "freakish" about a 6-1 or 6-2 girl.

My late wife (high school class of '82) was 6-1, our daughter (class of '12) 6-feet even. Neither took any crap for their height. Both played basketball. but I think their acceptance came more from being part of a team which also featured other tall girls than the fact they were both pretty good.

I realize not all girls, tall or short, play sports, but Jodi's one professed interest -- playing piano -- is said to be something she is suited for because of her wide hands. The current reduction -- I would never say elimination because people at schools all across the country are still bullied for many traits -- in harassment of tall girls is partially a product of many taking part in activities where their height is a plus. Tall girls who are "ordinary students" aren't automatically thought of as freaks if those who do play sports or model or whatever all else fields are now more open to tall women are not.
All scenario was so undemanding. We need to stop making movies about stereotyping beauty and making more movies about social issues like racism, gender inequality etc.

The entire movie was so predictable, you could basically guess what they are going to say next.

You guys, this is the funniest movie EVER! I watched it with my friend and we literally couldnt stop laughing This is hysterical Like, on another lever I will watch again and I def recommend it!!!!!!!

review_title: Train Wreck which is why I couldn't stop watching
review_detailed_main: Horrible movie with terrible acting!!! That being said my wife (who is 6'5) and I laughed the entire time. Needless to say we were extremely entertained at the horrible dialogue and the cheesy character development!!!

review_title: Underrated sweet tale with strong leads!
review_detailed_main: Jodi (Ava Michelle) is a teenage girl who has always had a difficult time at school. This is due to her being the tallest girl in her school and she is constantly discriminated against. After years of keeping her head low, this story captures her rise in confidence with the help of her two best friends Jack and Fareeda (Griffin Gluck and Anjelika Washington) and her sister Harper (Sabrina Carpenter) who show her just how beautiful she really is and how her insecurities will not define her. I really enjoyed this one from start to finish and this was mainly due to the fantastic performances from everyone involved. Michelle is a very strong central performer and she does a wonderful job in engaging the viewer from the very start in Jodi's story. Gluck is also brilliant as Jack who is madly in love with Jodi and the romance of this grows even better through the runtime. I was surprised to read so many negative reviews after catching this on Netflix; a lot of people found the approach of the film offensive or just extremely unfunny. I couldn't disagree more; I think it's a very honest film that handles its subject matter well while creating a good role model in its central character and portraying the abuse that comes from high school unsettlingly well. A big shout out to 'warthenee' and 'tallgirl-45656' who have stood up for Tall Girl on IMDB and related their own experiences to their emotional investment in the film. Lay back and enjoy!

..for the underdogs in movies, I always gravitate to their side.

The acting is great, Jodi/Ava was awesome in this and everyone got just what they deserved :)

review_title: I found it to be a great dramedy even as a guy
review_detailed_main:
I have dated a girl that was 6'1" and I'm a couple inches shorter, so maybe I can just relate to the humor better than most.

The drama is awesome, too. Everything about it is quite good, except for one scene. I laughed, I cried, and I could relate. It's difficult to make a film that does better than that.

It would have been a 9, except for that one scene. It's still a great film.
This was such a great movie, i loved it, it was more than a romance movie it was so much more, sooo meaningful and inspiring, it has such a great message, such a great movie 🔥🔥

This film is not as bad as a lot of the people are saying i enjoyed it giving 10 stars as I think the film deserves a higher score I have seen films rated higher that were worse than this film don't be put off watching this film.

I've wanted to watch this movie ever since it came out, I was so excited and it did not disappoint me. I didn't just feel bad for Jodi but I was connected to the movie on an emotional level, it made me feel like I wasn't alone. I might not be a Tall Girl like Jodi but I have spent the last few months learning to love myself, accept myself as me, learn and grow with people who will love me for my heart. I am usually not a huge movie person, but this movie was so empowering and heartwarming that it suddenly became one of my favourite movies. After watching "Tall Girl" I fell asleep feeling so happy and lifted as if someone had just come to me and said "It's gonna be ok. You'll get through it." I would recommend this movie to any girls between 12-25, who feel like they are not good enough, feel alone and want something to comfort them.

Here's a quick summary of the plot: 16-year-old Jodi is insecure about her height as she is taller than all the boys at school. Jack likes Jodi and wants to go out with her but she refuses because she doesn't want to date someone shorter than her. When a tall and hot Swedish exchange student, Stig, joins the school, every girl wants him. He ends up dating the popular girl, Kimmy. Soon after, Jack finds out that his family is hosting Stig. These two things cause many complications for Jodi. WATCH THE MOVIE TO FIND OUT WHAT HAPPENS!!!
Huge Steve What's S the story about this unusually tall girl who self conscious about it but overcomes it fan and this was a pretty good movie.

This movie was great! as an average height girl this showed the struggle that the "tall girls" of the world go through. the discrimination she faced brought tears to my eye, so sad and hurtful. I really liked the dad in this. trivia: he also is the dad in the hit classic "Diary of a Wimpy Kid"!

Excellent film. So well made! It was a dark and stormy night; I was huddled over a raging fire. Setting camp in the woods, when I stumbled across this movie via my intergalactic space shuttle. Suddenly, I knew it was the movie of my dreams. I grabbed my humuhumunukunukuapua'a (my pet fish) and pressed play. And boy was I in for treat! I sat through the whole thing, apart from momentarily getting up to chase a bear away for two hours. But the credits were fantastic. The font might I add, a masterpiece. Overall, a must watch, the fish and I (and the bear who decided to join) loved it!

The first time i experienced this piece of art was a few hours ago, it was very breath taking to see Dody with a J (the main charactor) bloom like a butterfly out of her cocoon through out this piece. i actually watched the whole thing... i did not vomit once :) all i have left to say is, this movie is better than fornite....go add me on fortnite btw. the cinematography was spectacular they did not drop the camera once i was VERY impressed. i personally relate to dody with a J the most....im 4'11" and lifes hard. i like the short kid too wish i could date him. the bratty popular girl is so disrespectful i was so suprised a lamp didnt fall on her while she was j-walking. lastly, the tall swittserland boi needs a hair cut :( -luv xoxo yours truly.

review_title: A Nice PG for the family or teens
review_detailed_main: I really dont get why people nit pick so much about this movie & it only gets a 5. We like wholesome PG movies suitable for the whole family without explicit content, which is hard to find. Is it completely spot on & realistic about everyting in real life ? Maybe not, but relax its just a movie. The main character Jodi & the boy that really like her are pretty genuine & nice. The girl is first portrayed as a plain Jane type but by the end her natural beauty & humility shows her very attractive. I thought the ending especially came together very nicely in an uplifting way with a very positive message coupled with the perfect song by Maggie Rogers, which I'd never heard before & which instantly became a favorite.

review_title: That ending though. Best ending I've ever seen!!
review_detailed_main: An 8 only for that ending alone. Just wow unreal. Loved it. The movie is ok as an evening watch and it's kinda different from others and will definitely make tall girls feel confident again.

This is one of the best movies I have ever seen! The movie had everything such as romance, overcoming fears, standing up for herself, sadness, and heartbreak. Even though I have seen a TON of movies in my life this is far by one of the best ones I have ever seen!

review_title: Heartwarming, and an ending i didnt know i needed (spoilers)
As a tall girl I love this
review_detailed_main: To those saying 6ft1 isn't that tall I'd love to know where you guys are from. I'm 6ft in the UK and have heard all the insults Jodi gets and more. I am an adult and I get random strangers come up to me and the street and in bars and make rude comments. I love her stand tall speech and the shoes Dunkel gets her. The only bit I found problematic was the milk crate, creepy and I didn't like the fact they clearly made him look like Duckie as much as possible...

Not a bad movie, good actors, good filming, but some things are cringy especially the end. The guy was manipulative and all. There are really good moments, I wish it has been like this all along.

I don't understand why there're a lot of bad rewiews. Personally I liked it. And I caught it perfectly, even cried some times because I know what bullying is like in real life. So, if you're wondering whether to watch it or not, I suggest you to watch it. BUT, the odd movie that isn't my typical watch I decided to take a peak see how first 20 mins were cause there's nothing else on and I was glad I did cause Wow first off I decided to check it out cause of Steve Zahan who rarely makes movies anymore and then I got hooked from beginning to end.
